summary: This is a transcript of a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview with Dr. [REDACTED], the former chief psychologist at MCC New York, conducted on October 27, 2021. The interview focuses on the psychological care, suicide risk assessments, and housing decisions for inmate Jeffrey Epstein during his incarceration at MCC New York from July to August 2019, leading up to his death. The psychologist details her interactions with Epstein, her hypotheses about the July 23 incident, and her belief that his death was a suicide.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate at the center of the OIG investigation into his death while in custody at MCC New York. The interview extensively details his psychological assessments, behavior, and housing.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.role: Chief Psychologist at MCC New York
persons.context: The primary witness being interviewed by the OIG. She was the chief psychologist at MCC New York during Epstein's incarceration and was responsible for his psychological evaluations and suicide risk assessments.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: An inmate who was celled with Jeffrey Epstein in the SHU. He was facing murder charges and the death penalty. Epstein initially accused him of assault on July 23, 2019.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.role: National Suicide Prevention Coordinator, BOP Central Office
persons.context: A central office psychologist who contacted MCC regarding Epstein's static risk factors (high-profile, sex offender) and was consulted on his housing.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.context: A psychologist at MCC who conducted suicide risk assessments on Epstein, including stepping him down from suicide watch to psychological observation on July 24, 2019.

persons.name: Warden [REDACTED]
persons.context: The warden of MCC New York during Epstein's incarceration. He made the decision not to house Epstein on the high-security Ten South unit and was involved in executive staff meetings.

persons.name: Associate Warden [REDACTED]
persons.role: Associate Warden at MCC New York
persons.context: An associate warden at MCC who was consulted when Dr. [REDACTED] stepped Epstein down from suicide watch to psychological observation.

persons.name: Lieutenant [REDACTED]
persons.role: SHU Lieutenant at MCC New York
persons.context: A lieutenant in the Special Housing Unit described as very regimented who regularly followed the psychologist's instructions.

persons.name: Paul Manafort
persons.role: Former inmate at MCC New York
persons.context: A high-profile inmate previously housed in the Cadre unit at MCC. Epstein expressed a desire to be housed in the same unit.

persons.name: Reyes
persons.context: An inmate who was Epstein's cellmate after he returned to the SHU. He was transferred/bailed out on August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

persons.name: Special Agent [REDACTED]
persons.context: One of the OIG agents conducting the interview.

persons.name: Senior Special Agent [REDACTED]
persons.context: One of the OIG agents present and conducting the interview.

connections.description: Dr. [REDACTED] was the chief psychologist responsible for Epstein's psychological intake, suicide risk assessments, and determining his watch status at MCC New York.
Epstein and Tartaglione were cellmates in the SHU. Epstein accused Tartaglione of assaulting him on July 23, 2019, but later expressed willingness to cell with him again.
Dr. [REDACTED] consulted with the national suicide prevention coordinator, Dr. [REDACTED], regarding Epstein's risk factors and housing.
Dr. [REDACTED] reported to and consulted with the warden and executive staff on inmate issues, including Epstein's housing. The warden made the final decision not to house Epstein on Ten South.
Epstein was celled with inmate Reyes after returning to the SHU from psychological observation. Reyes was removed on August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein alone.

events.title: Epstein's Initial Intake and Placement on Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein completed the Psychological Services Intake Questionnaire (PSIQ) and was placed on suicide watch as a precaution due to his high-profile status and sex offense charges, despite marking nothing concerning on the form.

events.title: First Suicide Incident and Assault Allegation
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell with a loose noose around his neck. He was placed on suicide watch. He initially told staff his cellmate Tartaglione tried to kill him, but later became vague about what happened.

events.title: Step Down to Psychological Observation
events.description: Dr. [REDACTED] took Epstein off suicide watch and placed him on psychological observation after a lengthy interview where he denied suicidality.

events.title: Transition Back to SHU
events.description: Dr. [REDACTED] transitioned Epstein from psychological observation back to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a cellmate, after he had been on watch status for nearly a week.

events.title: Epstein Signs a Will
events.description: Epstein reportedly signed a new will. Dr. [REDACTED] learned of this after his death from the newspaper and stated it would have been a major red flag prompting her to place him back on observation.

events.title: Cellmate Removed, Epstein Left Alone
events.description: Epstein's cellmate Reyes was transferred/bailed out. Epstein was left in a single cell overnight, contrary to psychology's strong recommendation that he always have a cellmate.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at MCC New York. Dr. [REDACTED] believes he died by suicide, citing hopelessness after bad legal news and the opportunity presented by being alone.

locations: One Battery Park Plaza, New York, New York (OIG New York Field Office)
1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, New York (U.S. Attorney's Office, SDNY)
keyFacts: The chief psychologist conducted three suicide risk assessments on Jeffrey Epstein during his incarceration: upon intake (July 8), after the July 23 incident, and once after a court return (likely August 1).

Psychology strongly and consistently recommended Epstein have a cellmate at all times for safety, but custody staff made the final housing decisions. His cellmate was removed on August 9, and he was left alone.

Dr. [REDACTED] had three hypotheses about the July 23 incident: 1) It was 'gamey' (manipulative) by Epstein or Tartaglione, 2) It was a rehearsal for suicide by Epstein, or 3) It was a real assault by Tartaglione. She believed all were equally plausible at the time.

The psychologist learned from the newspaper after Epstein's death that he had signed a new will on August 8. She stated this would have been a major red flag leading her to place him back on psychological observation.
Dr. [REDACTED] believes Epstein died by suicide, citing factors like receiving devastating legal news, feeling hopeless, and being left alone in his cell without a cellmate.
